articles.headline: Obama’s Budget Seeks to Loosen Austerity Reins
articles.snippet: The $4 trillion budget released Monday is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint, but buried in it are kernels of proposals that could take root even with a hostile Republican Congress.
articles.abstract: The $4 trillion budget released Monday is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint, but buried in it are kernels of proposals that could take root even with a hostile Republican Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $4 trillion budget that President Obama released Monday is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint for his final years in office, but buried in the document are kernels of proposals that could take root even with a hostile Republican Congress.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: G.M. Victim Compensation Program Seems on Track
articles.snippet: No payment offers have been rejected so far in the automaker’s effort to avoid the image-damaging litigation over defective ignition switches.
articles.abstract: No payment offers have been rejected so far in the automaker’s effort to avoid the image-damaging litigation over defective ignition switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: When General Motors decided last spring to set up a program to pay victims of accidents caused by a defective ignition switch in more than two million cars, its chief executive said the company was trying to live up to its “civic duty.”

articles.headline: Ukraine Rebels Upbeat After an Infusion of Aid
articles.snippet: Rebels feel they are within reach of surrounding a contingent of hundreds of Ukrainian troops dug into Debaltseve, a crucial rail hub.
articles.abstract: Rebels feel they are within reach of surrounding a contingent of hundreds of Ukrainian troops dug into Debaltseve, a crucial rail hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: HORLIVKA, Ukraine — The rebel commander casually led the way down a muddy trench, shoulder high with shaved walls of moist earth, his boots slapping at wooden slabs sunk into the muck. Finally, he reached an earth-covered observation post.

articles.headline: Lower Oil Prices Strike at Heart of Canada’s Oil Sands Production
articles.snippet: Suppliers of items like safety boots, cleaning services and housing have experienced uncertainty as excavation projects seek to cut operating costs.
articles.abstract: Suppliers of items like safety boots, cleaning services and housing have experienced uncertainty as excavation projects seek to cut operating costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — For as long as 400-ton dump trucks have been rumbling around the open pit mines of Canada’s oil sands, crews from Kal Tire have been on hand to replace and repair their $70,000, 13-foot diameter tires.

articles.headline: Slump in Oil Prices Brings Pressure, and Investment Opportunity
articles.snippet: Scores of debt-laden oil companies face struggles that could lead to layoffs and losses for banks and investors. At the same time, new fortunes stand to be made.
articles.abstract: Scores of debt-laden oil companies face struggles that could lead to layoffs and losses for banks and investors. At the same time, new fortunes stand to be made.
articles.lead_paragraph: American history is littered with oil busts that created big winners and losers.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Tax Reform Is the Cry, Until Details Are Offered
articles.snippet: President Obama’s budget calls for a lower overall tax rate, but also for a one-time 14 percent tax on all cash sitting overseas.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s budget calls for a lower overall tax rate, but also for a one-time 14 percent tax on all cash sitting overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a regular refrain from corporate America’s chief executives, “Corporate tax in this country needs to be reformed,” Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, has said repeatedly. Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, told lawmakers, “Apple has recommended to the Obama administration and several members of Congress — and suggests to the subcommittee today — to pass legislation that dramatically simplifies the U.S. corporate tax system.”

articles.headline: Measles Outbreak Proves Delicate Issue to G.O.P. Field
articles.snippet: The national debate on measles and immunization poses a challenge for Republican presidential hopefuls, who must reconcile modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.
articles.abstract: The national debate on measles and immunization poses a challenge for Republican presidential hopefuls, who must reconcile modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The politics of medicine, morality and free will have collided in an emotional debate over vaccines and the government’s place in requiring them, posing a challenge for Republicans who find themselves in the familiar but uncomfortable position of reconciling modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: A Heated Path Toward S.&P.’s Legal Settlement With Prosecutors
articles.snippet: An overflow crowd of government regulators spent a day last month ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement of an array of lawsuits against S.&P.
articles.abstract: An overflow crowd of government regulators spent a day last month ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement of an array of lawsuits against S.&P.
articles.lead_paragraph: When lawyers for Standard & Poor’s traveled to the Justice Department in Washington last month, they hoped to settle an array of government lawsuits and extinguish two years of bad blood. But within minutes of arriving, their plan collided with the demands of government negotiators — all 25 who attended.
